headline: Peanut Butter Haystacks
description: This haystack recipe uses 4 simple ingredients to make sweet, salty, simple, no-bake candy with chow mein noodles, butterscotch, and peanut butter.
name: Peanut Butter Haystacks

recipeInstructions.text: Line a baking tray with waxed paper.

Place butterscotch chips and peanut butter in the top of a double boiler over simmering water. Stir frequently, scraping down the sides with a rubber spatula to avoid scorching, until melted, about 5 minutes.
Stir noodles and peanuts into melted peanut butter mixture.
Drop dough by forkfuls onto the prepared tray. Allow to cool at room temperature until set.

review.reviewBody: I made a couple of changes, dark chocolate chips and chunky peanut butter, and Fiber One cereal. Delicious! And i used mini muffin papers and filled them! Clean!
Love love love these. Stores ran out of chow mien noodles so I used the thin pretzel sticks. Worked well!
So good! So easy to make!! They are always a big hit when I take them to parties, folks asking for more!
I loved making Haystacks.A good first try snack. Tasty and fun to make with Family.
I cut the peanuts and add cashews .. my grandmother made them that way and we love them ❤️
I brought these to a Christmas party and they were gone in 60 seconds.

Add mini marshmallows, and when putting on the wax paper arrange each stack more flat with a few of the noodles splayed out to look like bagpipes and you've got the recipe for Nancy Drew's Whistling Bagpipe Crunchies from the Nancy Drew cookbook. Ah, good memories from attempting those crazy old recipes. A tip if you ever find that book, never ever try the peanut butter soup. It was horrible, and I tried to make it twice thinking I messed it up, nope just a terrible recipe.
I’ve been making these for years and everyone loves them!

My next door neighbor made these when I was growing up. She told me the ingredients but I didn't remember the proportions. Thanks for this great recipe so that I could recreate a memory from my youth!!
They ended up sticky.

My family has made these for Christmas for decades! Our recipe includes multi-colored mini-marshmallows (mix in quickly so they don't melt). Stack these up high to look like a decorated Christmas Tree. The marshmallows are a delicious and colorful addition.
Quick, easy, and delicious. Thanks!

I have made these several times..always a hit! I have substituted the peanut butter with semi sweet chocolate chips and cashews for the peanuts. For making nests for Easter I have subbed the chow mein noodles with corn flakes.

These are tasty and quick! I remember them being called 'Hopscotch' back in the 60's. 
I make a switched up version of these using peanut butter, vanilla bark, dry roast salted peanuts, crispy rice cereal and miniature marshmallows. 
They're a huge hit as well.

This was a fantastic recipe. They turned out great. I didn’t have a double boiler so I used my dutch oven on the lowest setting on the stove top. I continually stirred. I don’t think they took very long to set up. Once I placed on wax paper, I just left on countertop maybe an hour or so. 
I want to try adding chocolate next time.
GREAT SWITCHED OUT THE PEANUT BUTTER FOR CASHEW BUTTER AND ADDED A HANDFUL OF COCONUT FLAKES.
No one from my family would eat these, so I guess that speaks volumes : (
I omitted peanuts and added marshmallows to half(for the kids) set up perfect!

I added 1 1/2 cups mini marshmallows and melted them with peanut butter and chips
I also use chunky peanut butter instead of creamy and skip the peanuts.
Delicious !
Great, easy recipe and I will definitely make it again! I did add a few more peanuts to my recipe.
Great, easy recipe and I will definitely make it again! I did add a few more peanuts to my recipe.
Great classic recipe from my childhood! I eased up on the peanut butter a little, and omitted the peanuts. Delicious and brings back so many memories!
Super easy, and very tasty! Left out the peanuts, but it was still very good.
I used CRUNCHY peanut butter and left out the peanuts. None left so I would say they were a hit!!!
I add about 1/2 cup more noodles and about 1/4 cup more nuts and i use cashews also
Family loved them!

Very easy. I love butterscotch! Even DH enjoyed them. I broke up the noodles a bit. Probably would a little more next time. I didn’t measure the noodles. Just added till it looked good. Will make again.

These are delicious but they never set up and remained sticky. No one seemed to mind though! I doubled the recipe but was very careful with my measurements . I will cut down on the peanut butter next time.
Easy and delish!!
I grew up on these, but with shoestring potatoes instead of chow mein noodles. My kids grew up on them too. What memories!
Perfect ratio of butterscotch and peanut butter!
I made with peanut butter chips yummy.

When I was a teenager a customer used to make some of this for us and it was soooooo good. For years I tried to figure out how she made it. I made this and it tastes exactly like hers! It is so delicious! I will definitely make it again.
wonderful-made one batch with butterscoctch peanutbutter chips,one with choc peanut butter chips-both great!
One of our family favorites! Delicious!
A sticky mess that wanted to fall apart but has a great flavor.
So simple to make and absolutely delicious! Don't change a thing about this recipe. Yum!
easy & so yummy!
Make these every year. Family loooooves these!
They good, especially for a Halloween Party!
My mom used to make these for her kindergarten class. They called them Bird Nest.

I didn't want to give a lower star rating and lower the overall rating because I think it's a good start but I had some issues. My haystacks only lost their stickiness and set up when they are cold (right out of the fridge). At room temperature they were sticky and fell apart so instead of using butterscotch chips next time I am going to experiment with making it with a sugar syrup cooked to soft-crack or hard-crack stage and a vanilla or butterscotch extract. 

I didn't have salted peanuts so I used chunky peanut butter and added a light sprinkling of coarse salt over assembled stacks and I loved them but my husband needed a little chocolate so I melted a few Reese's pb cups and drizzled that on half of the batch. 

Also, having experience with making a chocolate version of these for decades I know that too much peanut butter mixture could make loose stacks or waste a lot if it drips off as it sets so instead of dumping all of my noodles into my peanut butter mix I put some noodles in a pie plate and spooned some pb mixture over them and tossed and assembled them on Silpat mats in small batches. Also, some of my noodles were quite long so I had to break them in order to make bite sized stacks.

Last note on versatility of this mix, I ended up only using 1/2 of the PB mixture for haystacks so I used the rest as a sort of PB Ganache over a peanut butter pie and it was delish (though if I do it again I'll cut down on the sugar in my regular PB Pie recipe b/c it kicked up t
Instead of chow mein noodles, I use potato sticks. They taste awesome.

A very quick and easy recipe. Took less than 30 minutes from start to finish. These delicious haystacks are perfect when you need to bring something to a bake sale, office party or pot luck and have little time to make something. Will definitely make them again.
Took these to a friends anual pumpkin carving party and they were a big hit! Delicious! I will definitely make again!

I have made this recipe countless times now. My kids absolutely love them! The recipe easily doubles for a larger batch. I have even substituted pancit noodles when we were out of Chow Mein, still delicious.
Fun dish to make. Easy for anyone to make!

An old fave I haven't had since I was young. This is the perfect recipe for Haystacks! Here are my little tweaks:
1.Little less peanut butter. Easily overpowers the butterscotch.
2. Added some sweetened coconut. Added a great texure!
3. Crushed the noodles a litte to make them easier to eat. Pressed them down just a little too.
Thank You for posting this!
I prefer pretzel stick (3c) and rice chex (3c) and a little more peanut butter maybe 2 Tbsp
I added extra p butter and butterscotch to give it an even amount of chewy and crunch!
I make these but sometimes vary the type of chips but I always add rasins ....
simple and delicious!!!!!

Everyone always loves these, especially the kids. These are great to make when you have little assistants wanting to help! I basically double this recipe, using a whole bag of chips (11 oz.), 2 cans of noodles (5 oz. each) a whole cup of creamy peanut butter and a whole cup of peanuts which I coarsely chop. They always turn out great and everyone wants the recipe. Enjoy!

Very simple as most people have stated. I omitted the peanuts and added about 1/2 cup additional noodles. 

I microwaved* the morsels and the peanut butter for about 3 minutes on power 4. I stirred for about a minute and microwaved again for about 20 seconds to get the lumps out.

You also may want to add some baking paraffin in order to keep them together or from melting as quickly. 

*1100 watt microwave

Made this as is and it's great. I did add a few more peanuts. I have a similar recipe and this one is good too. Great for those of us who like butterscotch. My kitchen was warm so I stuck the wax paper lined sheet with them on it, in the fridge for a while to harden. In the winter room temp would probably be fine.

Yum! I made these around Christmas time. I did not have peanuts on hand but did have walnuts. I just chopped them coarsly and mixed them in. So yummy!!! 

Tip: I was such a novice and bought the wrong kind of chow mein. I bought the uncooked kind. You need to by the already cooked crispy kind that are brown in color.
Came out yummy but peanut butter flavor wasn't as prominent as I hoped. Will try to adjust amounts to improve this, but still was difficult not to eat more than one at a time!
Omitted the peanuts and did another cup of the noodles. It was a huge hit!

I've made these in the past, but that recipe was nowhere to be found in my archive so I looked to All Recipes for a replacement one. While these were easy and very tasty, they did not "set up" well and need to be refrigerated after about a half hour on the serving table or they get wet and loose, which was not the case with ones I've made in the past. I did not alter the recipe; in fact, purchased non-reduced fat peanut butter just for this (we usually use reduced fat kind). I was disappointed as I made them to give as gifts for my co-workers didn't like having to ask them to put their gifts in the fridge until they left for the day... If any one has a solution as to what I may have done wrong or how to correct this, I'd love to know! Thanks!
Good Recipe! I dont add peanuts, just use Chunky peanut butter.

Delicious and oh, so easy! I didn't bother with a double boiler but used a heavy pan and low heat. I made them once with organic peanut butter and once with Jif. The organic took longer to set up, but did eventually do so.
These are my husband's favorite!!!
Slam dunk! Followed the recipe to a T and they turned out great! What a hit! Thank you for posting!
Turned out great!!! I doubled the recipe and used store brand items. Very good and very simple.
Could not stop at 1, yummy
Good but really sweet.
I added three tablespoons of butter while melting everything and I think that was a good call.
Good stuff. Used Heath bar chunks instead of butterscotch. Wow!
Easy classic that the kids love!!

Made this recipe for Christmas at work and then had to make again for New Year's! Everyone loved them! I took another's advice and used the Fiber One cereal and came out better. If you want less mess and more consistent size use mini muffin papers on cookie sheet.
I was looking for a haystack recipe that I used to make as a kid. I think this is he same recipe. Yum!

I made these today with chocolate chips instead of butterscotch. I made them in just 7 minutes, which is awesome! They didn't set up as well as I was hoping they would though-even after an hour in the freezer, they were still sticky to the touch. I think it's the real peanut butter. I read some different recipes for this online and found some that just use peanut butter chips along with the chocolate chips and I think that might work out a bit better. These were still quite tasty though, both my husband and I enjoyed the flavor and texture. We might make these again, but probably with modifications so they are less gooey.

My family loves this! It's as simple as it gets and is great just as the recipe calls for but I like to add about a tablespoon of brown sugar for a maple taste. And then right before the noodles I stir in a teaspoon of my madagascar gold rum homemade vanilla. I've learned recently how to make my own vanilla and wow that's easy and great. And lastly I sometimes use all rice noodles instead of chow mein.

My family loves this! It's as simple as it gets and is great just as the recipe calls for but I like to add about a tablespoon of brown sugar for a maple taste. And then right before the noodles I stir in a teaspoon of my madagascar gold rum homemade vanilla. I've learned recently how to make my own vanilla and wow that's easy and great. And lastly I sometimes use all rice noodles instead of chow mein.

I followed the recipe and it wouldn't set up. I took the "haystacks" and tried pressing them into a cake pan to cut and that didn't work. I then tried adding more dry ingredients and that didn't help. I finally put everything in a big bowl, added powdered sugar, shook it all up and turned them into muddy buddy's.
These were delicious and easy!
I ate some of these when I was little couldn't find em so glad I did
Could eat these everyday! I mixed some with peanuts and marshmallows.
I made these with Rice Chex since I didn't have chow mein noodles. Love them!
Yummy! They were the first cookies gone at Christmas time!
I heated it together on the stove. Turned out great, very easy and very yummy. If I ever need a last minute dessert this is the one Ill make!

These are really good, but kind of sticky/gooey. Next time I am going to add a few more morsels, more peanuts, noodles and slightly less peanut butter. I stored them in the refrigerator and that helped. The candy is very good though. Thanks for sharing.
Delicious! I've made three batches this holiday season.

First time making the recipe and it was very easy. I decided to make a double recipe and the only thing that I changed was eliminating 1/4 cup of peanut butter. They setup just fine and tasted delicious! I had leftover Chinese fortune cookies so I just removed the fortune and dipped in the peanut butter and butterscotch mixture and it was also tasted great.
These came out perfect - I wouldn't change a thing!

These bring back such memories. Easy peasy when you use the microwave. It only took about 50 seconds and it was ready. Put them on a sheet pan and into the freezer. Had our little desserts in about 15 minutes. My kind of recipe!
Very easy, and very good! Fun to make with kids! Thanks for the recipe!
Loved this recipe! Reminded my daughter and I of the same treats my mom used to make! We didn't add the nuts... just personal preference! thanks for the memories!
This is an awesome recipe. I've never made these before and was pleasantly surprised that they're as easy as the recipe suggests they are. I will definitely be making these over and over again!
Cheap, simple, easy. But, be careful how you store them...they are really temperature sensitive! :) If you're out of the noodles, you can use pretzels, too.
fantastic!
Good-really sweet.

I really didn't think I would like these, myself but they were fantastic! I typically don't like stuff w/peanuts or PB much.... Used these "haystacks" for my daughters 1st B-day party theme for a barn yard bash!!!!
Great for a quick, easy Fall cookie. Best if put in the freezer overnight before serving.

These are really good. I doubled the recipe. Think I used a bit too much peanut butter, but after setting overnight they hardened up and although a little messy to eat my kids loved them!!! I will make again!!! Thanks for the great recipe!!
Update** I made these again and formed little bird nests and put little candy egg gum inside for Easter this year. We gave these out to the neighborhood kids and they were a great hit. Several Mothers asked for the recipe!!
I remember them being better when I was a kid. Maybe they weren't made with butterscotch chips.
They're a little messy. If you refrigerate them it helps.
Excellant, easy. It does make alot. Plane to share with neighbors.
Delicious!!! The saltiness of the chow mein noodles and peanuts goes perfectly with the sweetness of the butterscotch! LOVE these, but ate almost the whole batch by myself :/
